document.masterDocTitle: Phylogenetics, classification, and biogeography of the treefrogs (Amphibia: Anura: Arboranae)

Definition. Arboreal frogs with the pupil horizontally elliptical and the palpebral membrane unpigmented (
Figs. 16 A
and B); tadpoles with small anteroventral or enlarged ventral oral discs with a LTRF of 2 / 3 . Chromosome complement 2 n = 26 .

Content. Ninety-one species:
Litoria adelaidensis (Gray)
, albolabris* (Wandolleck),
amboinensis (Horst)
,

Distribution. Northern and eastern Australia , New Guinea and associated islands: Solomon Islands , New Britain , Vanuatu , and Moluccas Islands and Seram Island in Indonesia .

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The generic name is the Latin noun litoris meaning shore. Inasmuch as Tschudiâ€™s ( 1838 ) description was based on material he observed in Paris that was plundered from a British ship leaving Australia , he may have assumed that the frog lived near the shore. The gender is feminine.

Remarks. The following eight species for which molecular data are lacking are regarded as incertae sedis: castanea (Steindachner), hunti Richards, Oliver, Dahl & Tjatiradi, jeudii (Werner), louisiadensis (Tyler), multicolor GÃ¼nther, obtusirostris Meyer, richardsi Dennis & Cunningham, and vagabunda (Peters & Doria). At the present time they cannot be assigned with certainty to
Litoria
or
Dryopsophus .

Two-thirds ( 61 ) of the species of
Litoria
occur on New Guinea and associated islands. Only three of these (
L. bicolor , rothii ,
and
rubella
) also occur on Australia .
